Award.AwardTitle: Molecular basis of plant parasitism by a galling insect
Award.AbstractNarration: Grapes are the world's most valuable fruit crop, and a small insect called phylloxera is one of the grapevine's worst enemies. In the past it has almost wiped out vineyards worldwide. Phylloxera causes the plant to create specialized structures in which it lives and reproduces, called galls. This way of attacking plants is widespread and has evolved numerous times, and many important plant pests are gall-makers. Still, no one has any idea how the insect instructs the plant to create a new organ that benefits the pest. This project will attempt to understand this remarkable ability by examining the plant genes that are turned on or off by the insect in creating a gall. Charles Darwin suggested that galls resemble fruits and this project will focus on genes the plant normally uses to create flowers and fruits. The hypothesis is that plant genes normally involved in fruit production are activated by the insect in roots and leaves. Preliminary evidence to date supports that view. Since plants normally regulate flower and fruit production using hormones, a second hypothesis to be tested is that phylloxera manipulates plant hormones to create galls. These ideas will be confirmed by producing genetically-modified grapevines with key genes blocked. It should be impossible for galls to form on these plants. Findings from this project will not only explain a long-held mystery of nature; they will also provide the genetic information necessary for developing insect-resistance grapevines. The project is a unique collaboration among ecologists, entomologists, plant biologists and biotechnologists. Its results will be extended to the public via a collaboration with the Missouri School of Journalism and to grapevine breeders. The PIs are very active supporters of McNair and EXPRESS program students and a substantial number of undergraduates and K-12 teachers will also participate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This projecct investigated the interaction between grapevines and a parasitic insect called grape phylloxera. Grape phylloxera injects chemical signals into grape leaves that cause the plant to create a special home for the insect, called a gall. The insect feeds and reproduces inside the gall, which is a completely unique structure, never produced normally by the plant. Grapes are the world's most valuable fruit, and phylloxera is a devastating pest. But how phylloxera convinces grapevines to create galls is unknown.

  Many observers, including Darwin, have noticed that galls often resemble flowers or fruits. This project sought evidence that phylloxera hijacks the genetic programs plants use to create flowers and fruits in causing galls to form. The project's study of gene expression during gall formation found that many grapevine genes devoted to producing flowers are activated by phylloxera. These genes would normally never be activated in leaves. This supports the view that phylloxera hijacks flower/fruit development to create a gall. An experiment suppressing activation of a key flowering gene hindered gall formation, further supporting the hypothesis that gall development employs flowering/fruiting genes. 

  Plant hormones normally direct organ development. It is therefore logical that phylloxera might alter hormone concentrations to cause gall formation. This project developed new methods for measuring multiple plant hormones at the same time, and found that amounts of hormones that normally regulate flowering are changed in galls. Evidence suggests that the phylloxera insect may even supply a plant hormone to achieve these changes. 

  The economic impact of phylloxera can be huge. Results of this project have the potential to help improve the control of phylloxera, possibly through gene editing. Project participants found that the public regards galls as attractive and mysterious, which provides avenues for engaging nonscientists in plant biology. Two (female) postdoctoral fellows and 9 undergraduates received training in multiple disciplines by participating in this study. 

  An illustration showing the resemblance between some galls and flowers or fruits is attached.
